channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Labour Party Is Set for Landslide Win in U.K. Election
item.description: A nationwide exit poll indicated a decisive end to 14 years of Conservative rule. Labour’s center-left leader, Keir Starmer, was poised to become prime minister.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Bears Down on the Yucatán Peninsula
item.description: The storm, now a Category 2, has lost some power since slamming Jamaica and Grenada this week. A hurricane warning is in effect for the coast of the Yucatán Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israeli Leaders to Discuss Hamas Response on Cease-Fire Proposal
item.description: A senior White House official called progress in talks with Hamas “a breakthrough,” while Israel was more restrained, and both said major obstacles to a truce remained.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Michael D. Shear and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Debris covered streets in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: Justice Department Opens Criminal Investigation in Chinese Doping Case
item.description: The move escalates a fight with China and world antidoping officials, and will cast a shadow over the Paris Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: China’s swimming team for the Paris Olympics includes 11 athletes who have previously tested positive for banned substances.

item.title: Why More French Youth Are Voting for the Far Right
item.description: Most young people in France usually don’t vote or they back the left. That is still true, but support has surged for the far right, whose openly racist past can feel to them like ancient history.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden, Aida Alami and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:description: Young National Rally supporters distributing election leaflets in a Paris suburb.

item.title: Greece’s Six-Day Workweek: What to Know
item.description: The country, which already has the European Union’s longest average workweek, wants to add another day in some cases, bucking a growing business trend.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Greek workers demonstrated outside the Finance Ministry in Athens in May during a strike to protest low wages amid high living costs.

item.title: Iranians’ Demand for Their Leaders: Fix the Economy
item.description: In a series of interviews, virtually every resident of Tehran listed Iran’s sickly economy as the No. 1 issue for the country’s next president.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abbas sells restored furniture in Tehran. “Iran is a rich country, but that wealth doesn’t go into the hands of the people,” he said.

item.title: What to Know as Israel-Hezbollah Conflict Grows
item.description: A Hezbollah-Israel war could metastasize into a larger regional conflict that could dwarf the current fighting and draw in Iran and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning a member of Hezbollah in Baalbeck, Lebanon, in May, after he was killed in an Israeli attack.

item.title: First African-Born Member of German Parliament Won’t Seek Re-election
item.description: Karamba Diaby, whose 2013 victory was considered a win for equality, said he wanted more time with his family. But he has also spoken of the death threats he has received.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Karamba Diaby in the German Parliament in December. Bullets were fired through the window of his district office in 2020, and the office was a target of arson last year.

item.title: Europe Seeks to Solve the ‘Patriot Puzzle’ in Ukraine
item.description: With Ukraine clamoring for more air defenses, officials are trying to scrape together a Patriot battery from spare parts scattered across the continent.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: A German soldier at a presentation of NATO Patriot missile air defense systems in Silac, Slovakia, in 2022.

item.title: This English Naval City Is a Bellwether Seat. How Do Voters Feel?
item.description: As voters cast their ballots in a pivotal election, many in the southern English city of Portsmouth expressed disillusionment over what they see as national and local decline.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at a polling station in Portsmouth, England, on Thursday morning.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Sentences Producer to 13 Years in Prison Over Netflix Show
item.description: In a video plea for help, Abdulaziz Almuzaini — a dual Saudi-American citizen — described how the authorities had accused him of promoting extremism through a cartoon franchise.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Daniele Venturelli/Getty Images for The Red Sea International Film Festival
item.media:description: Abdulaziz Almuzaini at a movie festival in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, in November.

item.title: India’s Cable News Predicted a Big Modi Win. How Did They Get It So Wrong?
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s slim election victory has forced India to reflect on how fawning coverage may have obscured a wave of opposition.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Journalists watching election results in Mumbai last month.

item.title: What Makes the U.K. Exit Poll So Trusted
item.description: The first indication of results on British election nights has earned an unusually high reputation. Those behind it say that’s because of a big decision 20 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Ademola Bello
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vote count in 2019. British general elections are conducted entirely with paper ballots, counted by hand in the hours after polls close at 10 p.m.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Labour Projected to Win U.K. Election
item.description: Plus, Iran heads to the polls.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: If confirmed, it would be one of the worst defeats in the Conservative Party’s history.

item.title: Keir Starmer Is Poised to Be Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.description: The 61-year-old former human rights lawyer lacks the star power of some of his predecessors. “But he does look relatively prime-ministerial,” one analyst said.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, leader of the Labour Party, in Whitland, Wales, on Wednesday.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Churns Toward Mexico After Thrashing Caribbean Islands
item.description: Parts of Jamaica were badly damaged, but its prime minister said it could have been far worse.
item.dc:creator: Jovan Johnson, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: In Jamaica, residents who emerged from shelters took in a landscape of farmland that had been devastated, homes that had sustained damage and roads that were covered with toppled utility poles and foliage.

item.title: Russia Arrests Top Military Officer, Artyom Gorodilov, on Corruption Charges
item.description: Col. Artyom Gorodilov, who oversaw forces occupying the Ukrainian city where a massacre took place, was arrested and accused of large-scale fraud.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed civilian cars littered a main road leading out of Bucha, Ukraine, in April 2022. The city was occupied by Russian troops in the early days of the war.

item.title: Who Are the Key Players in the UK Election?
item.description: Millions cast ballots for parliamentary seats on Thursday. The party that wins the most seats usually forms Britain’s next government, and that party’s leader becomes prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Esther Bintliff and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The Parliament in London on Thursday. The political party that wins the most seats on Thursday usually forms Britain’s next government, and that party’s leader also becomes prime minister.

item.title: UK Election Night: When to Expect Results and What Comes Next
item.description: Almost every district is expected to declare a winner by 7 a.m. local time. A clear opposition victory would result in a quick transition of power.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a polling station in Saffron Walden, England, on Thursday.

item.title: Fight Over Seabed Agency Leadership Turns Nasty
item.description: An election over the future of a United Nations-affiliated organization could determine whether the Pacific Ocean floor will soon be mined for metals used in electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:description: Kiribati, a tiny island in the Pacific Ocean, is playing a critical role in the election of the next secretary general of the International Seabed Authority.

item.title: On Canada’s Coastal Islands, a Win for Indigenous Rights
item.description: British Columbia recognized the Haida’s aboriginal title to their islands decades after the Indigenous group launched a battle on the ground and in the courts.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Amber Bracken
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken forThe New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Britain votes in a long-awaited election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of the Labour Party, addressed prospective voters in London.

item.title: As Britain Votes, Change Is in the Air. Optimism, Not So Much.
item.description: The Labour Party is projected to sweep out the Conservatives after 14 years. But it would then inherit a “legacy of ashes.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters outside a polling station in Saffron Walden Town Hall, in Essex, England, today.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Batters Jamaica After Pummeling 2 Other Islands
item.description: The powerful storm, which devastated communities in the eastern Caribbean earlier this week, was headed next to the Cayman Islands.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Petite Martinique, Grenada, in the aftermath of Hurricane Beryl.

item.title: Sierra Leone Bans Child Marriage With New Law
item.description: A new law in the West African country of Sierra Leone allows child brides to annul their marriages and be financially compensated.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Mariama, a pregnant child bride, in Koidu, Sierra Leone, in 2020. She had married a 28-year-old man that year.

item.title: Israel Kills a Top Commander of Hezbollah, Which Replies With a Rocket Barrage
item.description: The escalation in violence across the border of Israel and Lebanon came as Western diplomats tried to head off a full-fledged war there.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Hezbollah said it had fired 100 rockets at military targets over the border with Israel as part of an “initial response” to the drone strike that killed a top commander.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: What’s at Stake in Britain’s Elections
item.description: Plus, an ally said Biden is considering leaving the race.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of Reform U.K., looks out at a crowd during a rally.

item.title: NOAA Flies Through the Rapid Intensification of Hurricane Beryl
item.description: Gathering data from directly inside the storm can help emergency managers prepare for what’s to come.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Inside the eye of Hurricane Beryl from the NOAA flight “Miss Piggy.”

item.title: Israel’s Repeated Evacuation Orders Take Toll on Already Weakened Gazans
item.description: The latest order, which the United Nations estimated affects about 250,000 people, was the largest since October, the U.N. said.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Khan Younis, Gaza, on Wednesday. The evacuation order issued for parts of the Gaza Strip this week was the largest since October, according to the United Nations.

item.title: A Family Loses 3 Generations of Women in India Crowd’s Panic
item.description: They had worked hard for years to make a life: “Now it’s over with the death of my dear daughter, wife and mother — in one single blow.”
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Vinod Kumar, center, mourning over the bodies of his wife and daughter, who died in Tuesday’s stampede.

item.title: Jay Slater’s Disappearance on Tenerife Spurs Online Sleuths and Speculation
item.description: Jay Slater disappeared on the Spanish island of Tenerife last month. His whereabouts sparked intense online speculation.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Claire Moses
item.media:description: A missing person poster that has been distributed with a photograph of Mr. Slater, who disappeared in Tenerife.

item.title: Why the Supreme Court Immunity Ruling Worries U.S. Allies
item.description: Legal experts say the U.S. Supreme Court ruling pushes past most of the norms in effect among American allies, adding more concern about the reliability of U.S. power.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Supreme Court granted an unprecedented expansion of executive power, worrying the country’s allies.

item.title: Israeli Air Base Is Linked to GPS ‘Spoofing’ Attacks
item.description: Misleading satellite signals have disrupted thousands of civilian flights. GPS, once considered navigation’s gold standard, is now vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:description: Researchers at the University of Texas at Austin found that one major source of spoofing is an Israeli air base. Spoofing can disrupt missiles but affects commercial flights too.

item.title: You See a Hedge. He Sees Something Else.
item.description: Tim Bushe decided to shape the hedges in his London neighborhood into a menagerie. They’ve become a local attraction.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A “reclining nude” hedgerow, which Mr. Bushe said was inspired by the artist Henry Moore.

item.title: Kings Battle for an Ancient Throne in Nigeria
item.description: Two men claim to be the emir of Kano, an ancient kingdom in northern Nigeria. Their struggle for power and influence is feeding into a wider competition ahead of the country’s next election.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Tom Saater for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emir Muhammad Sanusi II receiving his subjects in June. Emir Sanusi is one of two men vying for the throne in the emirate of Kano.

item.title: On the Kenya-Tanzania Border, an Elephant Hunting Ban Has Collapsed
item.description: Five bulls from the area around a Kenyan wildlife reserve have been shot and killed in Tanzania in recent months. The countries have very different conservation strategies.
item.dc:creator: Shola Lawal
item.media:description: A bull elephant just outside Amboseli National Park in southern Kenya.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Caused ‘Unimaginable’ Damage in Grenada, Leader Says
item.description: As the storm headed for Jamaica, officials were assessing what Grenada’s prime minister called “total” devastation on two of the country’s islands.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Reparación de un tejado en la capital de Granada, Saint George, el martes. Según las autoridades, el huracán Beryl causó muchos más daños en las islas de Carriacou y Pequeña Martinica, donde las comunicaciones quedaron interrumpidas.

item.title: How China and Russia Compete, and Cooperate, in Central Asia
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are courting regional leaders and pushing an alternative to the U.S.-led order.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Kazakhstan's Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, president of Kazakhstan, welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the international airport in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday.

item.title: They Came for Spiritual Revival, Only to Be Trapped in a Deadly Stampede
item.description: Family members streamed to hospitals in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh to identify loved ones after at least 121 people — nearly all women — died in a stampede at a guru’s gathering.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families visited hospitals late into the night to see if their relatives were among the scores killed on Tuesday at a guru’s gathering in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: China Seizes Taiwanese Fishing Boat As Tensions Rise
item.description: The authorities in Taipei have demanded that Beijing release the boat and its five crew members, who are being held in custody.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Hsieh Ching-chin, a spokesman for Taiwan’s Coast Guard Administration, said the crew members should not become pawns in the tensions between China and Taiwan.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Concerns about President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the weeks before the debate, President Biden kept up a grueling travel schedule.

item.title: An Uproar Over a Chinese Doping Case, Except in China
item.description: Chinese state news and social media has been virtually silent about 23 swimmers secretly testing positive in 2021, even as the issue is being debated widely abroad, including in Congress.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Chinese swimmers celebrating their gold medal in the women’s 4x200-meter freestyle relay at the Tokyo Olympics in July 2021.

item.title: Iran’s Runoff Election: What to Know
item.description: Two candidates from opposite camps will compete for the presidency after no one garnered the number of votes needed last week to win.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran featuring pictures of the reformist candidate Dr. Masoud Pezeshkian, left, and the ultraconservative Saeed Jalili.

item.title: New Haitian Leader Visits Washington Seeking Additional Support
item.description: Haiti’s newly selected prime minister, Garry Conille, met with Democrats on Capitol Hill as well as Biden administration officials, seeking more help to combat the unrest in his country.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Garry Conille of Haiti and members of his cabinet meeting with members of Congress at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Meloni Condemns Fascist Nostalgia Amid Scandal in Her Party’s Youth Wing
item.description: A news report used a hidden camera to show members of the youth arm of Brothers of Italy glorifying fascism.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The news report was a blow to Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, who has sought to cast herself as a modern, pragmatic leader of Italy, saying again and again that fascism belonged to history.

item.title: Thousands Flee in Gaza as Israel Orders More Evacuations
item.description: The Israeli military says its campaign will soon become less intense, but Palestinians were once again racing to escape the fighting in southern Gaza, including Khan Younis.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Iyad Abuheweila, Bilal Shbair and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing from Khan Younis following an evacuation order by the Israeli army.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: President Biden’s Lapses Increase
item.description: Plus, Israel’s generals want a truce.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the weeks before the debate, President Biden kept up a grueling travel schedule.

item.title: With Fists and Knives, Mobs Attack Syrian Refugees in Turkey
item.description: As economic woes grow in Turkey, groups of men have targeted Syrian refugees there. In response, fighters across the border in northern Syria have confronted Turkish soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: In Afrin, Syria, mourners carried the coffin of a man killed during protests against Turkey.

item.title: What Changes Would a Far-Right Government Bring to France?
item.description: The far-right party National Rally may end up governing France. Although it has evolved, its basic philosophy remains: Immigrants are a threat to the country’s safety and economy.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Jordan Bardella, the president of the right-wing party National Rally party, delivering a speech after preliminary results of the first round of the French parliamentary elections, in Paris, on Sunday.

item.title: Top US Official Holding Talks on Defusing Israel-Hezbollah Conflict
item.description: Amos Hochstein’s trip to France comes after comments by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken that Israel had “effectively lost sovereignty” near the border with Lebanon because of attacks by Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the State Department last week. On Monday he spoke of the dangers of the cross-border tensions between Israel and Lebanon-based Hezbollah militants.

item.title: Swedish Grandparents Can Be Paid to Babysit Under New Law
item.description: The Nordic country’s generous social services system now allows parents to transfer a portion of paid leave days to other non-parent caregivers.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Rob Schoenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stockholm, the Swedish capital.

item.title: U.N. Panel Adds to Chorus Calling for Russia’s Release of Evan Gershkovich
item.description: The U.N. Working Group on Arbitrary Detentions said the Wall Street Journal reporter was being punished for covering the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, during a hearing in Russia.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Roars Through the Caribbean: Photos and Video
item.description: A look at the destruction caused by Hurricane Beryl as it lashes its way across the region.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A car driving past a collapsed power line as Hurricane Beryl hits Kingston, Jamaica, on Wednesday.

item.title: Lucy Letby Found Guilty of Attempted Murder of Another Baby
item.description: Ms. Letby, who had previously been found guilty in a string of murders and attempted murders, was retried and found guilty of another attempted murder.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Journalists last year near Manchester Crown Court in northern England, where the nurse Lucy Letby received a life term for her previous convictions.

item.title: Stampede at Religious Event in India Kills More Than 100
item.description: The crush happened in hot and crowded conditions in Uttar Pradesh State, in northern India, and a medical official said the death toll could rise.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj, Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times

item.title: AfD Politician Björn Höcke Fined Again for Using Nazi Slogan
item.description: In his ruling against Björn Höcke, the judge said it was “essential that we counter the danger of old Nazi-era symbols from becoming acceptable again.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, center, was fined in May by the same court for using the same phrase.

item.title: North Korea’s New Must-Have Accessory: The Kim Jong-un Pin
item.description: With the introduction of the pin, Mr. Kim is said to be elevating his personality cult to the level once reserved for his father and grandfather.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media was said to show a senior official wearing a pin with the image of Kim Jong-un during a ruling Workers’ Party meeting in Pyongyang on Sunday.
